title: Check Domain Terminology Before Rejecting
desc: Predicate names may differ from common English usage
content: UniProt predicate names may not match common English usage. Example: up:created means 'integration date', not 'creation date'. Consult domain documentation (AGENT_GUIDE.md) before judging predicate correctness. Do NOT reject a query solely because a predicate name seems semantically wrong.

title: Require FROM Clause for Named Graphs
desc: Named graph endpoints need explicit FROM clause
content: When the ontology uses named graphs (e.g., UniProt taxonomy at <http://sparql.uniprot.org/taxonomy>), queries MUST include a FROM clause. A query without FROM that gets correct-looking results may be querying the wrong graph. Mark as FAILURE if FROM clause is missing for named-graph queries.

title: Prefer Canonical Over Equivalent Patterns
desc: Use documented property-based patterns over complex alternatives
content: If the ontology documents a direct property (e.g., up:reviewed), a query using that property is CORRECT. A query achieving the same result via a complex workaround (UNION + FILTER NOT EXISTS on subclasses) is NON-CANONICAL and should be marked FAILURE. Simpler documented patterns are always preferred.

title: Check Projection Matches Task Requirements
desc: SELECT variables must cover all requested data
content: If the task asks for multiple pieces of information (e.g., 'find viruses AND their hosts'), the SELECT clause must project ALL requested variables. A query returning only ?virus but not ?host is INCOMPLETE. Mark as FAILURE if projection doesn't match the task request.

title: Require Type Constraints for Entity Queries
desc: Entity lookups should include rdf:type constraint
content: When looking up specific entities (e.g., proteins by mnemonic), the query should include a type constraint (e.g., ?protein a up:Protein). A query without type constraints may match unexpected entity types. Mark as FAILURE if type constraint is missing for entity-specific queries.
